title: Details about KL loss and λ parameter
body:
Dear @adalca , (and other authors),

First of all, thank you for your research contributions.

Currently, I am trying to understand the ELBO loss used in the [MICCAI 2018](http://www.mit.edu/~adalca/files/papers/miccai2018_voxelmorph-pd.pdf) and [MedIA 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.03545) papers and I have two questions about the details:

1. Why is the KL term averaged over volume size instead of summed?
2. Why is setting λ=10000 equivalent to a diagonal standard deviation of 1 voxel for phi_z?

Examples of averaging are here:

https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/blob/699d754f2ffb6b7a73aa471c83d510f1ac2d3268/src/losses.py#L228

and

https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/blob/699d754f2ffb6b7a73aa471c83d510f1ac2d3268/src/losses.py#L198

I can imagine this averaging helps to keep the KL term in sensible range. However, I do not find any references of such averaging in the [MICCAI 2018](http://www.mit.edu/~adalca/files/papers/miccai2018_voxelmorph-pd.pdf) and [MedIA 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.03545) papers. For as far as I understand the derivations, the averages should be summations. It would be nice if you could elaborate on this?

Another thing is that in the [MICCAI 2018](http://www.mit.edu/~adalca/files/papers/miccai2018_voxelmorph-pd.pdf) paper it is mentioned that "the lambda factor is set to 10 000, which is equivalent to a diagonal standard deviation of 1 voxel for phi_z". To me, lambda would be the precision of the gaussian prior. It is not completely clear to me how a precision of 10 000 matches a standard deviation of 1 voxel in phi_z.

Very much looking forward to hearing your thoughts about this. 

Best, Tycho
